Hi Guys, join us for NASTY DREW: THE MYSTERY OF THE FAMILY JEWELS!

A erotic thriller show featuring: STRIPPING, COMEDY, MYSTERY, DRAG, BURLESQUE...and did we say STRIPPING?

Us lucky guys have been offered an amazing discount for the FINALE of the show run. Tickets are $15 general admission/ $28 VIP (VIP includes preferred seating, a VIP swag-bag, and meet-the-cast after show)

There's also a $20.00 food OR drink minimum at the venue (food is DELISH). My friend CHRIS HARDER (Google him, he's a porn star!) is the creator/star of the show and it's received rave reviews, here's the one from OUT Magazine:  http://bit.ly/1rUWABc

The $15.00 ticket promo code is: SECRET15 // $28.00 VIP promo code: ALIST 28

This will be a really sexy-fun dinner show, but space is limited so please get your tix ASAP: NASTY DREW TICKETS

**NOT GOING AWAY FOR MEMORIAL DAY?  NO PROBLEM! 

THIS EVENT IS PART OF OUR NEW 'STAYCATION SERIES', where we create a long weekend's worth of events for those of us staying in town over holiday weekends!

results.description:
Featuring: Nick Vatterott, Nick Turner, Aparna Nancharla, Jo Firestone, Ben Kronberg & more!

Tickets:
http://www.unionhallny.com/event/1170323-arguments-grievances-brooklyn/

Facebook RSVP:
https://www.facebook.com/events/1685671321686081/

Arguments & Grievances i​s a live comedy series and podcast featuring comedians debating outlandish topics with audiences choosing the victor. For over 5 years A&G has toured across the country headlining festivals and venues, in addition to the award winning monthly shows in Chicago and Denver. An outrageous enterprise exploring the heated issues of the day, including: "Hugs vs. Drugs", "Dr. Dre vs. Dr. Seuss", and "Batman vs. Spiderman", Arguments and Grievances is an impressive showing of live comedy, absurdity, and engaging fun.

"2014 BEST OF CHICAGO - VARIETY SHOW" - Chicago Magazine

"It's smart, high-stakes tomfoolery disguised in a brilliant, faux-brainy conceit....This show is a riot."
- Jason Heidemann, Chicago Tribune

"...it's funny, really funny.”
- Allison Kelley, The Chicagoist

"This excellent debate series enlists some of the city's funniest underground comedians.”
- Keith Griffith, Chicago Reader

results.description:
Friends,

Come and join us at Skyroom this Friday, May 27. We always have a great time at this venue.

Skyroom is conveniently located near Times Square, and many subway stations. 

This is a multi- Meetup group event, so you will get the opportunity to meet other members from my Meetup groups.

Do get there early so that I will be able to introduce you to the other invitees. Coming early also prevents you from the long lines.

Gents free before midnight. Ladies free before 1am.

Skyroom is definitely one of the top 5 rooftops in the city, and the Friday night party there is a lot of fun! Feel free to invite your friends to this event. 

Please note that the venue has a retractable roof so event will happen rain or shine.

Looking forward in meeting many of you!

Cheers,

Events Organizer

Rory

group.name: Jersey City Road and Trail Running Meetup

results.description:
Adirondack  High Peaks: Iroquois, Algonquin and Wright

*MUD issues may cancel this hike*

Summit 3 ADK High Peaks, including Algonquin - the second highest mountain in New York State and one of only 10 mountains in the northeast U.S. over 5,000 feet

***This should only be attempted by experienced hikers***

 ** PLEASE READ THE FULL DESCRIPTION BEFORE SIGNING UP FOR THIS HIKE **

* Not a beginner hike *


* This is a relatively long hike with multiple significantly steep sections.  Also, part of this hike is "off trail" - along an unofficial, unmarked herd path to Iroquois Mountain. *

----------

Hike Snapshot:


Total Mileage:  Approximately 10.5 miles out and back hike
Total Elevation Gain:  Approximately 4600 feet
Estimated Hike Time:  Approximately 7-8hrs (including breaks and dependent on conditions)

Moderate Pace (not slow) - You should have recent experience hiking multiple High Peak mountains (or their equivalent) in a single day to do this.  You should have previously (and recently) completed hikes of equivalent mileage and elevation gain to this hike to do this.  You should be getting regular, strenuous cardio exercise to do this.

Please be early - we leave on time


----------------------

Special Gear / Requirements:

$10 for parking in the Adirondack Loj lot; Gas and toll money for anyone you're car pooling with; Hiking boots; Non-cotton wicking clothing;  Multiple Layers of outer wear;  Trekking poles; MICROSPIKES (conditions may require traction), Headlamp and extra batteries: First aid;    National Geographic Trails Illustrated Map for the Adirondack Park: Lake Placid/High Peaks Region (Map # 742);  Compass;  GPS with relevant trail junctions, trailheads and summits programmed in, if you have one; camera!

****A good portion of this trail is above treeline, meaning we have no protection from the wind/elements.   Be prepared!    If the weather is going to be particularly bad, this hike may be cancelled or we may do a shorter hike in the area***

Meetup Times and Locations:


7:30 a.m. - Adirondack Loj Heart Lake Program Center front porch (near the parking lot entrance)


Please be early and give yourself time to find a spot in the lot, park, etc. - we leave on time.

Getting there: From New York State Thruway exit 24: Albany/Montreal. Immediately after the toll take the 2nd exit (exit 1N) for I-87 North towards Montreal.  Stay on I-87 for about 105 miles to exit 30.  Get off at Exit 30, then turn left on Route 9 and go just over 2 miles to the fork and keep left for Route 73.  Follow Route 73 for about 24 miles to Adirondack Loj Road on the left.  Make that left onto the Loj Road and take it for just over 4 miles until it ends at the parking fee booth. Pay the fee, enter the lot on the left and park.  We will meet around the front porch of the ADK Loj Heart Lake Program Center building just inside the entrance to the parking lot.

Route description: 

We start on the Blue Trail at the end of the parking lot.  Take the blue trail about 1.0 mile to the junction with the YELLOW trail.  We bear right on the Yellow Trail and follow it 1.7 miles to the junction with the Wright peak Trail on our left (continue straight to Algonguin, we tag Wright on way out).  From this point, it is 0.5 mile to the summit of Algonquin.  From the summit, we continue on the Yellow Trail approximately 0.7 miles to 'Boundary Peak'.  At this point, we follow an unmarked herd path (have compass and GPS ready) to the summit of Iroquois (about another 0.5 mile).   After tagging Iroquois we head back to the summit of Algonquin the way we came.   After summitting Algonquin again (!), we descend for 0.5 mile until we see the trail for Wright Peak on our right (a blue trail).   Take this trail 0.4 miles to the summit of Wright Peak, then back down the way we came, and take a right back onto the Yellow Trail.   

Once back at the Yellow trail (after summiting Wright) we'll make a right onto that yellow trail and head downhill for about 2.1 miles until it ends at an intersection with the Blue trail.  Then we'll turn left onto that blue trail which goes less than a mile back to the Adirondack Loj and our cars.

Our objectives as seen from Mount Colden on July 15, 2012:


 Our route is highlighted in blue below:

 Here is a description of the route we will be taking with more pictures:


http://www.offonadventure.com/2012/06/iroquois-boundary-algonquin-wright.html


PACE AND TIME:


We'll be keeping a moderate pace.  Note that moderate does NOT mean slow - though we won't exactly be trail running either.  Everyone coming on this hike should feel comfortable with keeping a moderate pace (not especially fast, but certainly not slow, either) over the mileage AND elevation gain, involved here.  Looking at the estimated hike time, in conjunction with the mileage and elevation gain estimates, will give you an idea of our planned pace.

** Be prepared to hike alone - and to find your way on your own - if you can't keep up or if you feel like hiking faster (or pick a hiking buddy who keeps a pace similar to yours and stick with them).  You should have a trail map of this area, and a compass, with you on this hike. **


**FAMILIARIZE YOURSELF WITH MAPS OF THE RELEVANT TRAILS/AREA AS WELL AS ROUTE DESCRIPTIONS BEFORE DOING THIS HIKE.** 

There will NOT be a sweep on this hike.  We will wait for people to regroup only TO A LIMITED EXTENT at trail junctions, and on the summits, but because of time constraints will not be waiting more than 10 minutes or so at any given junction, (though we will likely take breaks of 15-30 minutes on the summits, as long as the weather is good), so don't count on us waiting very long at junctions or on summits if you're too far behind. 

Again, there will be NO SWEEP on this hike. 

**** Everyone must come prepared to be responsible for themselves. ****

Depending on what time it is, we may head over to Lake Placid for a bite to eat be afterwards.

*******************


BE SURE TO READ THE BELOW INFORMATION BEFORE DECIDING WHETHER TO ATTEND THIS EVENT

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back.

See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

*** You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. ***

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.

Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.
results.name: ADK High Peaks: Iroquois, Algonquin and Wright

results.description:
So alot of groups are slated to do Presby this weekend. Weather forecasts are lack-luster at best and blooms are at about 50%.

I set the time early in the morning so we have proper light, but also because the garden gets very busy making clean shots impossible. There is a suggested donation of $8 per individual and $15 per season for artists and professional photographers. Check out their website for upcoming events: http://presbyirisgardens.org/wordpress/


If you are shooting with a DSLR and do not own an extension tube, reflector, or white card consider these things your next purchase as you will be doing alot of macro shots. I will update this post with a list of items you should bring.


Parking is available on Upper Mountain Ave and Highland Avenue. No fee will be collected for this meetup, however please know the attendance policy before you RSVP: http://www.meetup.com/New-Jersey-Photographers/messages/boards/thread/49785856
results.name: Presby Iris Gardens

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there on time so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER :)

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. You will not be allowed to play with cleats.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and pop-up goals.

Fun Play

results.description:
Join us for our fun, challenging, innovative, and FREE Spring Jump Start Boot Camp. Our weight-loss boot camp combines HIIT (over 1/4-mile) Strength Training (Body Weight during Phase I), and Core. This Coot Camp is designed by a U.S. Army certified Master Fitness Trainer, and is for all fitness levels.

ONLY 20 SLOTS AVAILABLE

Where: Prospect Park Parade Ground - Field 850 Parkside Ave Brooklyn, NY 11226

WORKOUT DETAILS:

Our Spring Jump Start Boot Camp spans 120-yards and consists of body weight and partnered exercises. Cardio includes short sprints and longer fartlek-like runs, and Plyometrics (Don't worry, no run interval is longer than the length of the training field).

Each interval is timed, and includes recovery.

WHAT TO WEAR:

o Comfortable gym clothes and running/cross-training shoes

WHAT TO BRING:

o A water bottle

o Towel

o Yoga mat

o Heart-rate monitor (optional)

Please RSVP through the Ticket Button, this is how we track who will be attending


FLTC-BK also offers private training, visit our site at: WWW.FLTCBK.COM

If you have any questions, please send us a message and we'll get back to you within 24 hours.

The instructable we will be following is here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Nerf-Vulcan-Sentry-Gun/

results.description:
Join us at 8am for a run to Hoboken Pier A and back.
http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/121375029

Yes, there is a waterfront route to Hoboken. Enjoy the fun of cruising around Hoboken Pier A; around the new park and children playground at Newport where you will feel if you are at the beach. Get inspired by the man made majestic views of Manhattan!

The mapped distance is approx. 5.88 miles. You may run less or more in that time. We turn back after running 30 min to be back at 9 am. Hyatt pier is .31 miles so a double loop gets some runners 6.5 miles on this run.

9 am we run to Liberty State Park, a favorite place to run for most of us. Run on!

results.description:
Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
1 game (7 v 7) : Two halves of 30 minutes each with a break in between

-Please bring a fun and chill attitude. Absolutely no rough playing, slide-tackling or berating others; You’ll be asked to leave.

-Turf, AG cleats, or sneakers - no wet ground monster spikes.

-$4.00 goes for maintaining the website, equipment, and organization.

Rules:

This is a chill game so please bring a chill attitude; no meatheads or a$$holes. Organizers have the final say (i.e. if a ball is out of bounds we call it). 
It’s a small pitch so no corners kicks; just throwins.

Directions:

How to get to Brooklyn Bridge Park PIER 2 Sports Field:

To get past the BQE, you must enter Brooklyn Bridge Park on foot either fromm the south (at Joralemon St. & Furman St.) or the north (at Old Fulton St. & Furman St.) Pier 2 is roughly halfway between these two entrances. We play on the artificial grass field at the far end of the pier, behind the basketball courts & roller rink.

Google these coordinates:[masked], [masked]

Brooklyn Bridge Park is accessible by several subway lines (A/C, 2/3, 4/5, F, R) and bus routes (B25, B63)

Cancellation: We'll play rain or shine. We'll only cancel if there are fewer than 10 people going, or if there's lightning in the area.

Late cancellations and no-shows will get you removed from future events. 

Game usually starts at 9:00. Please only rsvp if you plan on staying until the end.

results.description:
https://s.evbuc.com/https_proxy?url=http%3A%2F%2Fphotos2.meetupstatic.com%2Fphotos%2Fevent%2F6%2F1%2F0%2F4%2F600_441564836.jpeg&sig=ADR2i78jsKsgYf4yIzGS0AWqGTBiCb-qPw

Anthony’s Nose trail

60 Minutes North of midtown New York City, lies the quick but enjoyable hiking in and out trail known as Anthony’s Nose.  It offers similarly spectacular views to that of Breakneck Ridge and Mount Taurus;  In fact it offers a more sweeping view of the Hudson Valley and directly overlooks the scenic Bear Mountain bridge.  It offers a moderate and enjoyable hike to its peak.  A great hike for children, newer hikers or anyone looking for a spectacular view. 

https://s.evbuc.com/https_proxy?url=http%3A%2F%2Fphotos3.meetupstatic.com%2Fphotos%2Fevent%2F9%2F2%2F6%2F2%2F600_450097474.jpeg&sig=ADR2i78UF4SWnA8Wd73Lz1Fpfzs4MwTWGw

Location: South of Cold Spring, NY
GPS Trail Head Coordinates: [masked] [masked]
Duration: 120 minutes at moderate pace
Elevation gain: approx 790 ft.
Difficulty: Moderately Easy
Views: Hudson River, Hudson Valley, Bear Mountain Bridge, distant New York City Skyline (on clear days).

Reference 1; Reference 2; Trail Map 
Trail Video: https://youtu.be/1-SaGPCJx04

https://s.evbuc.com/https_proxy?url=http%3A%2F%2Fphotos4.meetupstatic.com%2Fphotos%2Fevent%2F6%2F3%2Fc%2Fe%2F600_441565550.jpeg&sig=ADR2i78I0Pdx2IDnqVji52IQI1ekv4h2nw

Wine Tasting

After hiking and having lunch at a local restaurant, we will have wine tasting nearby and taste 6 wines.

https://s.evbuc.com/https_proxy?url=http%3A%2F%2Fphotos1.meetupstatic.com%2Fphotos%2Fevent%2F8%2Fe%2Fe%2F7%2F600_450096583.jpeg&sig=ADR2i78_sUetphcQtmIHe-rKiNzU598qCA

Depart Date: May 28th Saturday; Please arrive 15 minutes earlier.

Depart 9:10 AM from Union Square: (Walgreen) Southeast corner of 4th Ave. & 14th St., New York, NY 10003 (Map) Subway lines (14 St-Union Sq): N, R, 4, 5, 6, L.

Depart 9:30 AM from Midtown West: (Garden City Deli) Northwest corner of West 43rd St. & 9th Ave, New York, NY 10036 (Map) Subway lines (Times Sq-42 St): A, C, E, 1, 2, 3, 7, N, Q, R, S.

Return: Expect to be back in Midtown West at 5:00 PM and Union Square at 5:30 PM

Cost: Early birds $35 if booked 7 days in advance; afterward $45. Bring a friend and save $5 each ticket.

Trip includes: Round trip transportation from NYC,  one bottle of water, 2.6 miles hiking at Anthony's Nose Trail, and wine tasting 6 difference wines.

Buy Ticket Here: http://may2016anthonysnose.eventbrite.com/ or you can Chase Quickpay me the amount indicated above to [masked] to avoid transaction fee (How to Use Chase Quickpay?) If Quickpaying, please indicate your boarding location. Your spot is NOT confirmed until your payment is received.

https://s.evbuc.com/https_proxy?url=http%3A%2F%2Fphotos4.meetupstatic.com%2Fphotos%2Fevent%2F8%2Fd%2Fc%2F5%2F600_450096293.jpeg&sig=ADR2i79ZTvzov-8-3mzmqqg3m_i8Dq_HQw

Requirements: 21+ only with Government Issued ID

Maximum: 15

Refund Policy:
* $10 processing fee if cancelled 7 days in advance; 
* 50% refund if cancelled 3 days in advance; 
* No refund for cancellation or no show within 3 days.

Pictures from Previous Hike at Anthony's Nose:
http://www.meetup.com/NYCAYS/photos/26423687/442213802/#[masked]

By RSVPing "Yes", you and your guest(s) are accepting the terms to the Waiver & Release of Liability set forth by NYC Active Young Singles.

results.description:
Let's join the Blockhouse run, and do some Spring running together in Central Park! The daffodils and cherry blossoms are out. 


"We do a fun and easy run on the bridle path, grass and rocks of Central Park, sometimes exploring historic and lesser-known features along the way."


All abilities are welcome. Partner into pace groups as needed. Lockers are available at the store. Rain or shine. Coffee and treats after!

https://scontent-lga3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xap1/v/t1.0-9/12348157_516652741825320_5165499368925402689_n.jpg?oh=acd86fbd5aa598de681cb9007291ad25&oe=578A7D9A

Trail map of CP

Weather: NYC forecast


Questions or comments? Type in comments section below. 


Happy spring and happy trails! 


Photo credits:  Blockhouse run club. Thanks for partnering!

____________

Note

This is not a Raw Trail-organized run. It is just a notice of a run some members are planning to do that is sent out to those who might want to join them. By choosing to join them, you agree that you are solely responsible for yourself, your own preparation, and for following trail etiquette<a href="http://www.trailrunner.com/news/trail_etiquette.htm"></a>, laws, park rules, and park safety guidelines. Thanks!

results.description:
If you are interested to join me for rock scrambles in Mohonk put your name on waiting list.
We'll decide what to do when we meet at visitor's center.

If you are afraid of heights or have FUN or you're claustrophobic this is NOT for you. NO BEGINNERS PLEASE!!!

This is full day event with drink & food afterward.
Fee: Please Note Mohonk Preserve charges a $12/person. fee for day use.

Driving direction:Take the New Paltz exit 18 off of the NYS Thruway. Go 7 miles west (through New Paltz) on Route 299 to the end: make right on Route 44-55. The Preserve Visitor Center will be 1/2 mile on your right.

Recommended Gear:

Gloves - Lightweight with good grip - Gardening gloves from Home Depot work great!
Headlamp with spare batteries.
Shoes with good grip - preferably with Vibram Soles.

Unless you know me personally, your RSVP is not valid unless you answer my RSVP questions fully.

results.description: This unlikely slice of city street is closed to traffic every weekend when dozens of vendors unfold their tables full of goods. Vendors tend to compensate for the out-of-the-way location by offering lower prices than found in the Chelsea lots, which makes it worth the trek.
results.name: Flea Market

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
Join us by helping home bound seniors receive healthy meals .

Organization:
for 30 years Meals on Wheels has served home bound elderly people in NYC receive meals.

help us bring over 2 million nutritious meals to 16,232 frail aged in every borough of New York City.

In addition, over 1,500 volunteers collectively spent 62,000 hours visiting and delivering meals to New York’s frail aged.

Gael Greene and James Beard founded Citymeals-on-Wheels in 1981 after reading a newspaper article about home bound elderly New Yorkers with nothing to eat on weekends and holidays.


Time: 9:00am – 12:00pm
Why: Because we are helping to end Senior Hunger
Event: Volunteer

https://youtu.be/XOTFxPoCUDg

Borinquen Plaza Senior Center

80 Seigel Street

Brooklyn, NY 11206

Catskill 3500 Series

Balsam Lake & Graham Mountains 

Summit 2 Catskill 3500 High Peaks, one of which is also one of the 5 Catskill fire tower mountains, and enjoy some lovely views!


** BE SURE TO READ THE FULL DESCRIPTION BELOW BEFORE SIGNING UP FOR THIS HIKE **

Total Mileage: approximately 8 miles
Total Elevation Gain: approximately 2000 feet
Estimated Hike Time: approximately 5-6 hours

Moderate/average pace - You should have recent experience hiking multiple Catskill High Peak mountains (or their equivalent) to do this. You should have previously (and recently) completed hikes of equivalent mileage and elevation gain. 

Please check the estimated mileage and elevation gain on this before RSVPing - and please read the description IN ITS ENTIRETY. 

Please be early - we leave on time. Well-behaved trail dogs welcome; I will likely be bringing my ultra-friendly German shepherd.

------------

Special Gear / Requirements: Hiking footwear, comfortable hiking clothing;  Enough food/water for the hike; Trekking poles; First aid;  Insulating shirt & rain jacket (just in case); Catskill Trails conference maps # 142 and/or National Geographic Illustrated Map of Catskill Park trails (map # 755); headlamp (just in case); camera!

Meetup Times and Locations:
9:00 a.m. - Mill Brook Road Parking lot -  coordinates: N[masked] W[masked]

Getting there:Take the New York State Thruway to exit 19: Kingston. Keep right for Route 28 west. After 35 miles turn left into the entrance road to Belleayre Ski Area (county route 49A).  Pass all of the Belleayre parking entrances, staying on 49A for about 5.5 miles.  Turn left on county route 49 and go about 1.4 miles then turn right by the old barn on Mill Brook Road - go 2.2 miles to the parking lot on the right.


Route description:


Approximately 8 miles distance, with approximately 2000 feet of total elevation gain. 


Park at the trail head at the end of the Beaverkill Road. The public road dead ends at this spot and a private road continues to the Balsam Lake Lodge. We will take the blue-blazed Dry Brook Ridge Trail and hike about .9 miles to the second juncture with the Balsam Lake Mountain Trail. After about .1 miles, we will take the herd path to Graham Mountain. The trail starts a rather gentle ascent with some places descending slightly. After about 1.1 miles a sharper ascent climbs 600 ft. in .8 miles to the summit of Graham Mountain.

On the return, we will take the red-blazed Balsam Lake Trail for .75 miles to the summit / firetower, then descend via the same trail until it meets back up with the Dry Brook Ridge Trail, taking that back to the parking area.

PACE AND TIME:


We'll be keeping a moderate/average pace. Best estimate of total hike time is about 5-6 hours, including breaks.

**FAMILIARIZE YOURSELF WITH MAPS OF THE RELEVANT TRAILS/AREA AS WELL AS ROUTE DESCRIPTIONS BEFORE DOING THIS HIKE.** 


*******************


BE SURE TO READ THE BELOW INFORMATION BEFORE DECIDING WHETHER TO ATTEND THIS EVENT

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back.

See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

*** You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. ***

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.

Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

results.description:
The core of the oven is built, but we're not done yet! Learn the basics of masonry and lay bricks to build the outer facing of the oven.

Join the team to lay the beautiful red brick facing that will make this oven a twin to the Old Stone House and protect it for generations to come.  We'll also be beautifying the oven area.

This final phase of oven construction will extend over several weekends throughout the month of May. Feel free to join all day long or for just a couple of hours. No prior bricklaying experience is required!

Also, when you come help build the oven, we'll add your name to the brass dedication plaque that will be put on the finished oven. You'll go down in history as a Builder of the Oven!

We'll provide work gloves and tools.  Please wear closed-toe shoes and clothes that can get dirty.

See you there!

results.description:
World Stamp Show-NY 2016 Javits Convention Center May 28-June 4, 2016

This once-a-decade event takes place May 28 through June 4 at the Javits Center in New York City. Admission is free.

Designated as a “World Stamp Exhibition” by the Fédération Internationale de Philatélie (FIP), WSS-NY 2016 will provide all show-goers with a unique experience combining our passion of stamp collecting with the fun and excitement of everything New York City has to offer. Start making your plans to attend now!

We anticipate over 250,000 people will pass through the show doors over the eight days. Featuring more than 200 dealers and postal administrations selling and buying philatelic material of all kinds, 4,146 frames of competitive exhibits, a Court of Honor and Invited Exhibits displaying priceless stamp rarities, auctions, 355+ hours of seminars/meetings, youth and beginner activities, and first day ceremonies sponsored by the U.S. Postal Service, U.N. Postal Administration and other nations, everyone attending will have plenty to do and see.

Come celebrate stamp collecting with us!

There is no charge for this event!

Total Body Bootcamp!
930am at Clove Lakes Park. Meet by the basketball courts by Clove and Victory. 

Workouts are for all fitness levels whether you’re just starting out and this is your very first workout or if you’ve been pushing hard for years. You will sweat, you will work, you... will HATE IT, but YOU’LL LOVE IT!

The workout is approximately one hour long with breaks. Each participant should bring water and a towel. Optional accessories for the workout include a yoga mat and light dumbbells if you have them. We will have some extra equipment on hand but please bring what you have.

It’s a total body workout beginning with cardio, then moving into lower body strength training, then upper body strength training then lastly ending with a core workout all while moving to the beat of some kick ass music!!

So please, come on out and get your sweat on! And spread the word!

PAGE SHARES ARE VERY MUCH APPRECIATED TO HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

Here is more information from JONES BEACH website:

Shop

Air Show - May 28 & 29, 2016

</a><a href="http://www.jonesbeach.com/index.php?view=article&catid=57%3Aevents-2014&id=384%3Aair-show-may24-a-25&tmpl=component&print=1&layout=default&page=&option=com_content&Itemid=100055"></a>World Renowned Naval Aviators the Blue Angels will peform over Jones Beach during next year's Memorial Day Weekend celebration, according to the U.S. Navy.<a href="http://edition.cnn.com/2014/03/14/us/blue-angels-fly-irpt/">http://edition.cnn.com/2014/03/14/us/blue-angels-fly-irpt/

The Blue Angels suspended air shows in 2013 because of federal budget cuts, known as the budget sequestration.  The sequestration remains in effect, but the Angels have booked 65 shows in 34 U.S. locations, according to a press release.  "Our peformances provide a unique opportunity to inspire millions to connect with and support our service members, and we are looking forward to an exciting 2014 season," said Blue Angels' commanding officer and flight leader Commander Thomas Frosch.

The Angles fly F/A-18 Hornets.
</a> <a href="http://www.navy.mil/navydata/aircraft/fa18/shornet.html">

U.S. Navy Blue Angels

U.S. Navy  F-18 Super Hornet click here 

also performing: GEICO Skytypers US Army Parachute Team Golden Knights

</a>

SAT-5/28  & SUN-5/29
10AM - 3PM

Admission Price: FREE
Parking Cost: $10.00
Train/Bus Service:<a href="http://www.mta.info/lirr/getaways/Beach/JonesBeach.htm">http://www.mta.info/lirr/getaways/Beach/JonesBeach.htm


Get there early. In the past, this show has easily seen 200,000 people fill up the beach on a single day. It is not unusual for the parking lots to be filled by 11:00am (if not earlier). When this happens, the parkways are closed and people are turned away. So, it is probably a good idea to arrive before 10:00am, or as early as reasonably possible.

SUNSCREEN. Bring it. You will be in the sun for over five hours. Trust me, you will need plenty of it.

BAGS, BACKPACKS, AND COOLERS ARE OK (this is a beach you know), but keep in mind THEY WILL BE SEARCHED so don't bring too much stuff along with you. It will also get crowded near show-center, and extra baggage could make movement difficult. There is a nice fast-food style restaurant on the East end of the beach, and refreshment vendors will be located along the boardwalk. If you want to keep costs low, you may want to bring along your own drinks and snacks. There will be no bleachers or seating of any sort (with the exception of the VIP Chalets that require a separate entry fee purchased before the show), so bring a blanket to sit on, or a foldable chair. If you plan on sitting close to the water, you might want to bring a jacket or long-sleeved shirt. Even though the air temperature may be warm, the waters will still be cold and can cause the area right by the shoreline to be surprisingly chilly.

EARPLUGS are suggested for the younger viewers (under 3 years), but aren't a bad idea for some of the grown-up viewers as well. The jets can get loud, and you might get stuck next to some annoying guy who won't shut up about his cats.

Photography is always fun at an air show, but there are several things to keep in mind, and you should know the limits of your camera. Even though the planes will be close, they will still be far enough away that you will need a decent amount of zoom. The beach faces South, directly into the sun, so most everything will be backlit all day. Also, the air tends to get quite hazy, making it difficult to get a crisp shot. Don't let these handicaps prevent you from bringing your camera, however. You never know what kind of moments you will be able to capture.

KITES ARE PROHIBITED. They can easily distract the performers, and that could result in some rather nasty stuff. Please leave these flying machines at home.

NO PETS. Of course, this excludes animals that aid the handicapped. Unless that animal happens to be a ferret, and if you are using a ferret to lead you around everywhere, you will probably have trouble getting to the show in the first place.


May 28 & 29, 2016
Airshow commences at 10:00 a.m.
Airshow concludes at 3:00 p.m.

WE GOING BOTH DAYS.



Arrive early, Glasses,Sunscreen, Bring lunch, water, hat, suntan lotion. Old shoes or slippers are a good idea because we will be walking on Broadwalk.

Tips for show
Arrive early 
Dress in beach attire 
Bring some warm clothes in case of a temperature change 
Glasses 
Sunscreen 
Hats 
Beach towels and chairs 
Check the website regularly for last minute news items and updates

COST FREE IF YOU HAVE MONTHLY OR WEEKLY UNLIMITED METRO CARD.


OR

</a><a><a></a><a></a><a></a><a></a><a>http://www.jonesbeach</a>;...

Bethpage Federal Credit Union Air Show 
Jones Beach State Park


Saturday May 28,2016. WE GOING BOTH DAYS.

and

Sunday, May 29, 2016  WE GOING BOTH DAYS.

Shop

Air Show - May 28 & 29, 2016

</a><a href="http://www.jonesbeach.com/index.php?view=article&catid=57%3Aevents-2014&id=384%3Aair-show-may24-a-25&tmpl=component&print=1&layout=default&page=&option=com_content&Itemid=100055"></a>World Renowned Naval Aviators the Blue Angels will peform over Jones Beach during next year's Memorial Day Weekend celebration, according to the U.S. Navy.<a href="http://edition.cnn.com/2014/03/14/us/blue-angels-fly-irpt/">http://edition.cnn.com/2014/03/14/us/blue-angels-fly-irpt/

The Blue Angels suspended air shows in 2013 because of federal budget cuts, known as the budget sequestration.  The sequestration remains in effect, but the Angels have booked 65 shows in 34 U.S. locations, according to a press release.  "Our peformances provide a unique opportunity to inspire millions to connect with and support our service members, and we are looking forward to an exciting 2014 season," said Blue Angels' commanding officer and flight leader Commander Thomas Frosch.

The Angles fly F/A-18 Hornets.
</a> <a href="http://www.navy.mil/navydata/aircraft/fa18/shornet.html">

U.S. Navy Blue Angels

U.S. Navy  F-18 Super Hornet click here 

also performing: GEICO Skytypers US Army Parachute Team Golden Knights

 </a>

SAT-5/28  & SUN-5/29
10AM - 3PM

Admission Price: FREE
Parking Cost: $10.00
Train/Bus Service:<a href="http://www.mta.info/lirr/getaways/Beach/JonesBeach.htm">http://www.mta.info/lirr/getaways/Beach/JonesBeach.htm


Get there early. In the past, this show has easily seen 200,000 people fill up the beach on a single day. It is not unusual for the parking lots to be filled by 11:00am (if not earlier). When this happens, the parkways are closed and people are turned away. So, it is probably a good idea to arrive before 10:00am, or as early as reasonably possible.

SUNSCREEN. Bring it. You will be in the sun for over five hours. Trust me, you will need plenty of it.

BAGS, BACKPACKS, AND COOLERS ARE OK (this is a beach you know), but keep in mind THEY WILL BE SEARCHED so don't bring too much stuff along with you. It will also get crowded near show-center, and extra baggage could make movement difficult. There is a nice fast-food style restaurant on the East end of the beach, and refreshment vendors will be located along the boardwalk. If you want to keep costs low, you may want to bring along your own drinks and snacks. There will be no bleachers or seating of any sort (with the exception of the VIP Chalets that require a separate entry fee purchased before the show), so bring a blanket to sit on, or a foldable chair. If you plan on sitting close to the water, you might want to bring a jacket or long-sleeved shirt. Even though the air temperature may be warm, the waters will still be cold and can cause the area right by the shoreline to be surprisingly chilly.

EARPLUGS are suggested for the younger viewers (under 3 years), but aren't a bad idea for some of the grown-up viewers as well. The jets can get loud, and you might get stuck next to some annoying guy who won't shut up about his cats.

Photography is always fun at an air show, but there are several things to keep in mind, and you should know the limits of your camera. Even though the planes will be close, they will still be far enough away that you will need a decent amount of zoom. The beach faces South, directly into the sun, so most everything will be backlit all day. Also, the air tends to get quite hazy, making it difficult to get a crisp shot. Don't let these handicaps prevent you from bringing your camera, however. You never know what kind of moments you will be able to capture.

KITES ARE PROHIBITED. They can easily distract the performers, and that could result in some rather nasty stuff. Please leave these flying machines at home.

NO PETS. Of course, this excludes animals that aid the handicapped. Unless that animal happens to be a ferret, and if you are using a ferret to lead you around everywhere, you will probably have trouble getting to the show in the first place.


May 28 & 29, 2016
Airshow commences at 10:00 a.m.
Airshow concludes at 3:00 p.m.

WE GOING BOTH DAYS.



Arrive early, Glasses,Sunscreen, Bring lunch, water, hat, suntan lotion. Old shoes or slippers are a good idea because we will be walking on Broadwalk.

Tips for show
Arrive early 
Dress in beach attire 
Bring some warm clothes in case of a temperature change 
Glasses 
Sunscreen 
Hats 
Beach towels and chairs 
Check the website regularly for last minute news items and updates

DIRECTION TO JONES BEACH BY USING SUBWAY AND BUS:


ALL THE WAY TO JONES BEACH AND COST FREE IF YOU BUY YOUR WEEKLY UNLIMITED METRO CARD  or its FREE with WEEKLY OR MONTHLY UNLIMITED METRO CARD:


One day Gateway trip to Jones Beach cost youFREE  if you use WEEKLY UNLIMITED Metro card and subway from Manhattan to Jones Beach. If you have WEEKLY OR MONTHLY Metro Card than no cost you nothing extra.

Subway,Bus N-4 and and then Bus N-88 all have FREE TRANFER with your metro card. Tansfer are free on subway and bus ride if you buy WEEKLY GATEWAY METRO CARD  or if you have a  MONTHLY Unlimited Metro Crad.

Take E train from Manhattan to JAMAICA CENTER/ARCHER AVENUE and walk towards to bus station and take Long Island Bus # N-4 To Freeport rail station. than take N-88 from Freeport Rail station to Jones Beach and get off at West Boat House in Jones Beach.

To get 9:45 am to Jones Beach, You should start from Manhattan by E train about 6:30 am so you can reach at Jamaica Center/Archer Ave in Queens before 7:20 am.Take 7:30 am Bus # N-4 from Parsons/Archer Ave when you get off from E train subway. IF YOU MISS THE 7:30 BUS, THERE IS BUS EVERY 15 MINUTES AFTER THAT.Take n-4 long island bus at 7:30 am bus take you to Freeport at 8:28 am than take N-88 bus at 8:35 am and reach Jones beach at 9.10 am.

You can take another N-4 bus at 7.50 am to get to Freeport at 8:48 AM.next N-88 at 9.05 AM ,next bus N-88 is 9.35 am, then next N-88 at 10.05 am.

If you want to come late or noon time, still you can get there.There is several speaical bus N-88 provide from Free Port LIRR station for Jones Beach.

WHEN YOU TAKE YOUR RIDE BY SUBWAY TRAIN E. to JAMAICA CENTER/ARCHER AVE- THEN WALK TOWARDS TO GET N-4 BUS .  N-4 BUS TAKE YOU TO FREEPORT LIRR STATION, WHERE YOU WILL TRANSFERED TO N-88 BUS FOR JONES BEACH. PLEASE GET OFF AT FIRST STOP ONE'S BUS N-88 ENTERED IN JONES BEACH AREA AND WALK TOWARDS TO BEACH.YOU WILL FIND YOU NEXT TO WEST BATH HOUSE A TWO STORY BUILDING.

OUR MEETING PLACE IS INFRONT OF WEST BATH HOUSE, YOU WILL  SEE SIGN FOR FRIENDLY ICE CREAM PARLOR. AND YOU WILL SEE ARMY STRONG TRUCK. THERE IS REST ROOM THERE.THAT LOCATION FOR US TO MEET FROM 9:30 AM TO 10.15 AM AFTER WEWALK AROUND THAT AREA.

venue.name: Take the 9:43am Metro North Train to Pougkeepsie, NY

results.description:
Please read carefully: This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people you see registered on your Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending from all groups please contact the event host at <a>[masked]</a>

If you love the outdoors or just want to get out of the city for a day and don't feel like committing to our  Memorial Day Camping Weekend, then join us just for the day!  On the Saturday of Memorial Day Weekend we have hired a second van so that you can join all those on our camping trip for all the fun activities planned for that day. 

Here is how it works:

-You will take the 9:43am Metro North Train from Grand Central (or drive) to Poughkeepsie.

-Dave and the camping group will meet you in Poughkeepsie at 11:30am where you will set out for a fun hike at Lake Minneaska and Awosting Falls.  The hike is about 3 miles and will take about 3 hours including a stop for lunch overlooking the valley.

-After the hike you will head to a local winery or hard cider farm.

-You will end your day with a fun happy hour on the shores of the Hudson River with at the campsite where you can relax, kayak, swim and enjoy a cocktail and appetizers.

-At 6:30pm you will be driven back to Poughkeepsie for the 6:54pm train back to NYC.

$90 includes: round trip transportation to and from the train station and all activities, all park fees, guides, taxes and tips. Happy Hour on the river with wine, beer, soft drinks and appetizers.

*** MUST CLICK ON THE BELOW LINK TO PRE-PAY FOR YOUR TICKET *** https://www.eventbrite.com/e/memorial-day-weekend-day-trip-hike-winery-riverside-happy-hour-tickets-25439939544

Not included: lunch (bring a bag lunch), winery fee's (not everyone drinks) and train fare.

Can I come alone?  Yes 97% of those attending will register on their own.

What should I wear?  Summer casual, hiking shoes or sneakers with treads.

How hard is the hike?  There are some inclines.  This would be a 5 out of 10.  It helps to be in shape.  There may be roots and rocks on some paths.

What if it rains? The trip is canceled if the conditions are unsafe and you will be refunded.
results.name: Memorial Day Weekend Day Trip: Hike, Winery & Riverside Happy Hour

results.description:
PLEASE BRING BOTH A BLUE T-SHIRT & A WHITE T-SHIRT.                                                                                                                                                                                 Started by a group of soccer fanatics who love to play the Beautiful Game and wanted to create a meetup for individuals of all levels. 

Our Mission: Play safe, get your workout on & HAVE FUN!!

The Lowdown: 

1. Play safe,  excessive aggression will NOT be tolerated (the precinct is across the street...LOL!!). 

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

3. Pitch Location: Between Baxter & Mulberry St. with additional entrance on Worth & Bayard St. 

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street. 

5. HAVE FUN!

See you Downtown! 

Terms and Conditions of the participating in our group:

PLEASE READ THESE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF USE CAREFULLY. 
BY USING THIS WEBSITE, YOU AGREE TO THESE TERMS AND CONDITIONS. 

JOINING AND SIGNING UP FOR DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT: 

I certify that I am 18 years of age or older and that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore I, individually, hereby release and discharge, DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER Organizers and Co-organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER programs or activities. 

DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER Organizer and its Co-Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

The Downtown Pickup Soccer Team

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Fleet Week New York, now in its 28th year, is the city’s time-honored celebration of the sea services. It is an unparalleled opportunity for the citizens of New York and the surrounding tri-state area to meet Sailors, Marines and Coast Guardsmen, as well as witness firsthand the latest capabilities of today’s maritime services. The weeklong celebration has been held nearly every year since 1984.

Event: General Public Ship Tours

Time: 8 a.m. - 5 p.m.

Lines may be capped at 3 p.m.

Ship tours will be held on Piers 88S and 92S in Manhattan; the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal in Brooklyn; and USS The Sullivans Pier in Staten Island. Events are free and open to the public.

Kevin's Cell #[masked]
results.name: Fleet Week New York

results.description:
LEADER: Jeffrey Sovelove ([masked])

RATING: B 5.5 B

We will start at Turtleback Rock trailhead at 10AM. Please arrive early for introductions and to get situated. See the Essex County Parks Commission website http://www.essex-countynj.org/p/index.php?section=parks/sites/so for directions. Bring lots of water, and wear hiking boots. We will take the orange trail down to Hemlock Falls and also see the famous Turtleback Rock. Heavy/steady rain cancels. No pets please. Joint ADK/Sierra Club hike.

Note that this hike is part of a larger group, the NJR ADK. Most hikers sign up via our printed schedule (see below) and not through Meetup, so though the number of attendees may appear small, we generally have a group of 10-20 on any given hike. 


*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

results.description:
Meetup/Hangout – 9:45 am

Whole Foods (Union Square) -- upstairs cafe. Show up a bit early to say hi, chat, and drop off any thing you don’t want to run with: jackets, bags, phones, etc. Somebody will always stay to watch the stuff.

Run – 10:00 am

Run 1 mile, 3 miles, 5 miles, or whatever you want. We'll head to the West Side Highway together. No pressure and no limits. Totally informal. Lots of different paces for lots of different people. Even walking speed is encouraged!

Brunch – 10:45 am

Whole Foods has ALL THE FOOD. Come get some.

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It’s that easy. First we run, then we eat!

results.description:
Thrive in the Park is a place to meet friends, have fun and get fit.

Our *donation based workouts are designed by fitness experts and are for everyone, at any level of fitness. 

WORKOUT DETAILS:


The work out consists of body weight exercises (ex. pushup, sit ups, squats, lunges, jumps), team competitions, partner exercises, and cardio (jumping jacks, jogging, sprints, jump rope).

We do not count reps, but rather have a "do as many as you can in 1 minute" style of encouragement.

If you have any questions, please send us a message and we'll get back to you within 24 hours.

WHAT TO BRING:


A water bottle, your determination and your *donation*. All donations are invested back into Thrive in the Park

TESTIMONIALS:

Achelle - "#ThriveInThePark is the workout I look forward to all week! Not only do I get an incredible full body workout, but it's a fun and encouraging group to be apart of!"

Maria - "#ThriveInThePark is what I look forward to every week, there is nothing cooler than working out, laughing, and bonding with great people who care for their health. Rain or shine we thrive."

Andie - "#ThriveInThePark I never thought I would enjoy waking up early on a Saturday, but now I look forward to it, fun workouts with friends that keep you motivated to push yourself!"

Dani - "#ThriveInThePark I Love everything about it! Such a positive way to bring community together for some weekend activity. The guys/girls that lead the workout and stretches bring such great energy to the group, we basically laugh the whole time - until the lunges and burpees come along, no one laughs at those."

Devon - "#ThriveInThePark provides a necessary jolt of inspiration and aspiration to anyone looking to improve their life."

Ben - "#ThriveInThePark is all about community and giving back, I couldn't think about a better way to spend my Saturday mornings."

Marco - #ThriveInThePark is great because it connects mind body and soul! We learn new techniques, we motivate each other and meet interesting people from all over the world!"

HISTORY:

Thrive in the Park started in the spring of 2014. We believe in giving back to the community and in creating ripples of kindness, strength and gratitude. It is our hope that you too, will go into the world and create these ripples. 

We can't wait to see you!

LINKS:

http://www.ThriveInThePark.com 

Sponsored by: http://www.soRipe.com

results.description:
Continuing with the flower theme, pretty soon this garden will be showing off their irises, and they're quite a collection. I can't say enough about it, because there are just too many varieties to see. It's an awesome show, and I hope you can make it, which brings me to a small conundrum: I don't know when they're going to bloom. 

I've checked the place out, looked for pamphlets and everything, but I found no data on them. The latest word is in a couple of weeks. This being the case, I won't make a definite date until I know more. When I do you will be the first to know. In the meantime, here's a link to the garden that explains more about it, just not a blooming date.

http://presbyirisgardens.org


Hopefully the weather will be a bit warmer than it is now. Other than that, stay tuned for more info.

SPRING/SUMMER SCHEDULE

• Saturday @10am - Morningside Park

• Sunday @12pm - Morningside Park

• Tuesday/Thursday @5pm - Riverside Park


Hello!

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

It's important to RSVP so that you can get updates through the Meetup app. Also PLEASE bring a dark shirt and a light shirt so that it helps distinguish teams.

See you soon!

Damien 

[masked]
[masked]
@ProfDuchamp

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the C local (B on weekdays) to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball/softball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

[img src="">

results.description:
One hour from NYC on the Hudson line of the Metro North RR is the town of Cold Springs. It offers a wide range of recreational and cultural activities. There is fine dining, historical tours, and unique shops.  outdoor activities include boating - cycling - hiking - kayaking - etc.  There is also plenty of quiet space at the picturesque waterfront, and in the well maintained parks. 

People that have been there before say it  is a lovely place and you do not need a car to get around.  Everything starts when you get off the train. 

We will meet in Grand Central and go from there

Since no one wants to stay overnight at this time..... we will just make this a "day trip".

I would like to visit Cold Spring and research the possibility of having a  "Nature Lovers Weekend Getaway"  in Cold Spring for the group sometime this Summer.  Since most of us do not have a car, I would LOVE  to find a getaway that we could enjoy using public transportation...  Come and help me check it out.

60+ NYC young at heart Message Board › Cold Spring: Message Update. 
Group Organizer
New York, NY
Good morning Members,  This is my 3rd attempt to communicate with you about Cold Spring......

After doing more research, and getting advice from members that have been to Cold Spring........I decided to change the date until Memorial Day Weekend.  At this point in time the weather should be warmer and ALL the activities that Cold Spring has to offer will be up and running.

Since so many members say they will be going,..... I would like to plan a tentative itinerary for the afternoon. Of course everyone will be free to come and go as they please but you will know where to group plans to be at any  given time.  I am listing 7 activities.  Please choose 3 that you would like to participate in.  This is your chance to speak up to insure that you will have a great time.  Please list your choices and comments in the " Comments"  section of the "Cold Spring Meetup Venue"  ( On the Meetup Website).

(1)  Sight See Main Street  (2)  Lunch in "Nice" Restaurant.  (3)  Bought / Brought Lunch in Waterfront Park.  (4)  Boating: paddle boat,  canoe,  Kyack  (5)  Hiking Wooded Trail  (6)  Strolling City Park....  There is also an art museum  in Beacon NY. with bus service back and forth.

please read the comment I wrote  below....  The comment starting ......  OK,  I think it is working now ....... I will send another email and post it on the message board on Tuesday May 17th....    If you get the email,..  give me a comment.
results.name: Visit Cold Spring,  NY:  A Day Trip   for Adventure and Fun.

results.description:
We'll start out from an established subway line, the Lexington Avenue line,. The meeting point is on Lexington Ave and 77th St. below at the downtown side by the booth attendant. We will then walk south to the new Met extension, the Breuer, then to the new Apple Store . We’ll then go East towards the East River and then make our way West and North while enjoying the old architecture on some of these amazing old masterpieces (a school, a church, 2 libraries and several residential buildings). We'll then walk on second avenue to see some of the new structures that are related to the development of the second avenue subway.
We will end the tour on Fifth Avenue by Central Park and near the Metropolitan Museum of Art. as well as the Onassis Reservoir which was once known as the Croton Reservoir. I will relay the history of Central Park as well as the history of the Old Croton Aqueduct (as this once was an active reservoir for NYC). Please note the $20 MeetUp Member charge per person for this special tour. Discount price for students and senior citizens is offered at $15. This tour's value is actually $250 (for 10 people) as that is my charge for most of my private tours. Kindly provide me with exact payment at the venue. Like my other walks, I do not plan to cancel the walk as this is a multi group event. Also since I set a 20 person limit, please cancel your RSVP if you decide your initial plans have changed. After the tour, you can then enjoy some FREE or pay-as-you wish museums.

Please feel free to text or call me at[masked] with any questions. Enjoy,

DESCRIPTION:

Fleet Week is a United States Navy, United States Marine Corps, and United States Coast Guard tradition in which active military ships recently deployed in overseas operations dock in a variety of major cities for one week. Once the ships dock, the crews can enter the city and visit its tourist attractions. At certain hours, the public can take a guided tour of the ships. Often, Fleet Week is accompanied by military demonstrations and air shows such as those provided by the Blue Angels.


ATTRACTIONS:

• Parade of Ships

• Musical Performances

https://cbsnewyork.files.wordpress.com/2014/05/uso-show.jpg?w=625

• Aviation Demonstrations

• Many Aircraft Carrier and Battleships to Tours.

• Demonstrations and much More.

results.description:
Hip Opening, Psoas Releasing Workshop

Saturday, May 28

10:30 am - 1:30 pm

$45

Tight hips? Stiff lower back or hamstrings? Pain in the legs or glutes? Due to our culture of sitting for extended periods of time or overactivity like running or cycling, our the muscles in the hips can get tight, compressed, or weakened.

In this workshop, we will:

* Delve into hip opening poses, learning benefits and alignment to safely gain more range of motion
* Learn the anatomy of the psoas, a hip flexor muscle that connects the upper half of the body to the lower half. Using yoga therapeutics, we can release the psoas, gain stability in that region of the body, and experience freedom of movement
* Reflect on how emotions can get "stuck" in the hips

People often ask if we are "doing yoga for 3 hours straight" -- in the workshops that I offer, the answer is "no." Workshop-style sessions are set up to give us spacious time to delve into poses, ask questions, and get an integrated experience without rushing.

Class size is limited to 8 people
Workshops will be held in my home studio in
Clinton Hill (11238)

Potluck lunch to follow each workshop!
Please bring a dish to share

You must pre-register to attend this Meetup. For more information and to register, please contact Chia-Ti via email: [masked]

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

results.description:
This year is the 100th anniversary of Central Park's Shakespeare Garden! We'll sketch in the garden and also move on to sketch the nearby Belvedere Castle as well. One of the most classic spots in the park.

We'll meet at 79th and Central Park West and head into the park. Note: there is actually no 79th street here! The spot is directly across the street from the main entrance to the Natural History Museum.

Any problems on the day of the event, I can be reached at [masked]. 


Looking forward to sketching with you!


----------

In case of rain, I will let people know early in the morning if it is canceled, and then reschedule for another day.

----------

What makes our Meetups different from other art groups and classes? There's no instruction, but we like to share our work, and chat and be inspired. Share tips and learn from people in a casual environment where all levels of artists are welcome! Don't be shy to ask anyone anything!

• We sketch for a bit, usually 45 minutes or so, and then get back together and share our drawings, and then sketch again, etc. There's usually time for 3 or 4 sketches.

• Please bring your own supplies - anything you like to work with - pens, pencil, watercolor, pastel, small sketchbook or large paper, iPad, whatever suits you.

• We hand out nametags so everyone can meet one another!

• We take photos to share on the site later. Take a bunch!

• Please take care to make sure we do not leave any trash behind. Please also leave the dogs at home; they tend to step on the artwork. Thanks. 

• This Meetup is FREE and everyone at all skill levels is welcome!

----------

How does the Wait List work? If the event is full, rsvp to be added to the Wait List. If someone from the regular list cancels, the first person on the Wait List is automatically bumped up to regular attendee.

Please note that if you add a comment below it will spam everyone with an email, so please use your judgement.
results.name: Shakespeare Garden 100th anniversary sketch!

results.description:
Inline skate lesson for Beginner to intermediate skaters. 


Cost of this class is: $25 per individual class, $45 for 2 classes or $60 for package of 3 classes; discount packages should be paid in full; fees are collected before class begins, however we suggest that you to pay in advance, using Pay Pal option.


Please note that you must have complete set of protection gear and helmet to participate in class. 

Central Park Sightseeing is now renting skates!
The website does not make it clear that they rent skates….but they do!  $25 for 24 hours. www.centralparksightseeing.com
Please rent from them, if you need to and be sure to have them mention that Central Park Skate Patrol sent you there.


We meet Just inside the West 72nd Street Entrance to Central Park at 11:00AM, The class leaves for the lesson area by 11:10AM.  We will then walk to the practice area so we are geared up ready to skate by 11:30AM.

Reminder – wrist guards, helmets, knee and elbow pads are required to participate in class. These items have to be purchased in advance. Please check all of your gear before coming to class to see if it fits properly. Make sure the wheels, buckles, straps, snaps, laces and everything else is in good working order.

Please note that if it is raining or the lesson surface is wet, we will NOT have the class. Cancelation of class will be posted in advance.
If you have any other questions, please post them on this page or text/call me at [masked]

results.description:
Beginner Bhangra sessions are for you

- if you want to learn how to groove at a club/party

- if you are all for letting loose at a wedding

- if you are Indian and still can't do the "Chaffa" (don't worry, we'll show you how;)

- if you are not Indian and want to join the latest dance trend

- if you want to have a blast while learning an awesome dance skill

- if you just want to learn the basics for the love of Bhangra

The class begins with a warm up, followed by basic step-by-step instruction of different Bhangra steps each week, and finally choreography training to put those moves to the beat!

No previous dance experience is necessary - just bring in your smile! Our Instructors are professional, friendly, and open minded. So come on in and let swag emerge!

Wear comfortable clothes and shoes.

The drop-in price is $20 and can be paid here on meetup, or head over to our website www.nycbhangra.com/nycbhangra/signup for other options to pay.

Checkout our other Learn & Sweat BHANGRA classes too!

results.description:
For all of you guys who are sticking around the city for Memorial Day, come kickoff the weekend with a picnic - yay!! Our first picnic of the year back in April had a fantastic turnout. Let's keep it up!

RSVP now and share details with your friends.

SHOPPING & TOURING THE MARKET (11:00-11:30am)


Meet our group at the info booth in the center of the market. I'll have a rainbow flag and a cooler on wheels. You can shop with the group or branch off and do your own thing. We'll then meet back at the booth at 11:30am. If anyone needs more time, they can continue shopping and meet us in the park. Jon is a Certified Health Coach (www.bkhealthcoach.com) so if it's you first time at the market, let him know and he'll give you a tour of the market and help you shop.

PICNICKING (11:45am-1:00pm)

Everyone is invited to come picnic in the northern section of Prospect Park (see map below) which is a short walk from the market. I'll have some free food and drinks to munch on and you guys can share whatever you'd like with the group (no pressure). Will be a fun time to relax, hang out, chat, walk around, and do whatever's clever.

I'll have a cooler in case you need to stash away milk or other cold foods you bought at the market. 

**Small donation day-of  or on-line is appreciated and will help keep the group stay active**

Click "chip in" or Venmo @bkhealthcoach.com

Highlights from our April Picnic

This 2-Day comprehensive workshop explores visual storytelling with dynamic camera movement and skillful actor blocking.

Through extensive, daily hands-on exercises, participants will learn to visualize the scene, work with actors, strategize with storyboards, and evoke the essence of the script: DRAMA!

Participants will learn how to visualize, choose optimum camera positions, camera movement, and lens choices in relations with actor blocking.

Through this process, participants will understand how to convey tone, mood, and style, as well as give the film a distinct look that belongs to the director's unique vision.
